War of the Dwarves and Orcs

wikitext.*:
The '''Kings of Durin's Folk''' were those of the [[House of Durin]] who ruled as kings, even when in exile. The kings were all descended from [[Durin|Durin the Deathless]] of the [[First Age]]; in fact, five of the kings after Durin I were held to be reincarnations of him by the [[Dwarves]]. No complete list of all kings is known. The table below shows the names of those Kings who have been recorded, or whose existence could be deduced. In the table all information was obtained from ''The Lord of the Rings'', Appendix A, "Durin’s Folk"{{App|Durin}} unless otherwise indicated. The "Realm(s)" column indicates which place or places the kings ruled from during their reigns.
NameBirthDeathRealm(s)Historical Notes
[[Durin|Durin I]] the DeathlessBetween {{YT|1050}} and {{YT|1250|n}}{{GA|19}} Late [[First Age]][[Moria|Khazad-dûm]]One of the seven [[Fathers of the Dwarves]] and founder of the Longbeards, [[Durin's Folk]]. He ruled his people for centuries - so long, in fact, that he became known as the "Durin the Deathless" - but eventually, he died before the end of the First Age. He established the city of [[Khazad-dûm]] and began his reign there.
[[Durin II]]UnknownUnknownKhazad-dûmNothing is recorded about his reign.
[[Durin III]]UnknownUnknownKhazad-dûmHe was the [[King of Khazad-dûm]] at the time of the forging of the [[Rings of Power]] (sometime between {{SA|1500}} and {{SA|1590|n}}{{App|SA}}) and a great friend of [[Celebrimbor]] the [[Lord of Eregion]]. He received one of the [[Seven Rings]] (later known as the [[Ring of Thrór]]) as a gift from his friend. The [[Alliance of Dwarves and Men]] in the North is said to have come to an end during his reign.{{PM|Dwarves}}
[[Durin IV]]UnknownUnknownKhazad-dûmNothing is recorded about his reign.
[[Durin V]]UnknownUnknownKhazad-dûmNothing is recorded about his reign.
[[Durin VI]]{{TA|1731|n}}{{TA|1980|n}} †Khazad-dûmHe was King when the [[Balrogs|Balrog]] was awakened in {{TA|1980|n}}.{{App|TA}} After he was killed by it the Balrog was called [[Durin's Bane]] and Khazad-dûm was known as Moria.
[[Náin I]]{{TA|1832|n}}{{TA|1981|n}} †Khazad-dûmHe reigned for just one year before he was also slain by [[Durin's Bane]].
[[Thráin I]]{{TA|1934|n}}{{TA|2190|n}}[[Lonely Mountain|Erebor]] He led a great part of his people away from Khazad-dûm into the North and founded the [[Kingdom under the Mountain]] in {{TA|1999|n}}. The [[Arkenstone]] was discovered during his reign in the [[Lonely Mountain]].
[[Thorin I]]{{TA|2035|n}}{{TA|2289|n}}Erebor, [[Ered Mithrin]]Learning that his people were regrouping in the [[Grey Mountains]], Thorin I abandoned Erebor and reestablished the throne in the Ered Mithrin in {{TA|2210|n}}.
[[Glóin (King of Durin's Folk)|Glóin]]{{TA|2136|n}}{{TA|2385|n}}Ered MithrinNothing is recorded about his reign.
[[Óin (King of Durin's Folk)|Óin]]{{TA|2238|n}}{{TA|2488|n}}Ered MithrinTowards the very end of Óin's reign, in T.A. 2460, the Shadow returned to [[Dol Guldur]] in [[Mirkwood]] with increased strength; and in c. T.A. 2480 [[Orcs]] began to spread again in the [[Misty Mountains]] in order to block all passes into [[Eriador]], whilst [[Sauron]] populated [[Moria]] with his creatures.
[[Náin II]]{{TA|2338|n}}{{TA|2585|n}}Ered MithrinIn {{TA|2570|n}}, the prosperous Dwarves began to suffer [[War of the Dwarves and Dragons|attacks]] by the [[Dragons]] of the North.
[[Dáin I]]{{TA|2440|n}}{{TA|2589|n}} †Ered MithrinHis reign came to a swift end when he was slain by a [[Cold-drakes|cold-drake]] before the entrance to his halls.
[[Thrór]]{{TA|2542|n}}{{TA|2790|n}} †Ered Mithrin, Erebor, exile, [[Dunland]]He led his people out of the [[Grey Mountains]] back to the Lonely Mountain. He had been [[King under the Mountain]] for more than 180 years when the dragon [[Smaug]] descended on the mountain and [[Sack of Erebor|sacked]] it. He escaped the destruction, and went wandering in the wild before settling in Dunland. Later, he went to reclaim Khazad-dûm where he was murdered by [[Azog]] the Orc-chieftain, a crime that provoked the [[War of the Dwarves and Orcs]].
[[Thráin|Thráin II]]{{TA|2644|n}}{{TA|2850|n}} †Dunland, [[Ered Luin]]He avenged his father's death with the defeat of Azog's Orcs at the [[Battle of Azanulbizar]]. In the early part of his reign, he dwelt in [[Dunland]], but he later moved northwest to the [[Ered Luin]] west of Eriador and established a [[Thorin's Halls|new realm]]. Before his reign ended, he resolved to return to Erebor, but while wandering in the wild he was captured in {{TA|2845|n}} and died in the dungeons of the [[Necromancer]]. Consequently, the [[Ring of Thrór]] was lost to [[Sauron]].
[[Thorin|Thorin II Oakenshield]]{{TA|2746|n}}{{TA|2941|n}} †Ered Luin, Erebor He ruled as King in the Ered Luin for many years, but like his father before him, he was determined to return to his ancient home of Erebor. Accompanied by [[Gandalf]] and [[Bilbo Baggins]], he led a [[Thorin and Company|troop of companions]] into the east, and against all hope recovered the Lonely Mountain from Smaug. After Smaug's death, Thorin was slain in the [[Battle of Five Armies]]. The only remaining descendants of Thrór's line, Thorin's nephews [[Fíli]] and [[Kíli]], were also lost in the battle. So the Kingship passed to the line of [[Grór]], Thrór's younger brother; specifically, to his grandson [[Dáin Ironfoot|Dáin II Ironfoot]].
[[Dáin Ironfoot|Dáin II Ironfoot]]{{TA|2767|n}}{{TA|3019|n}} †Erebor Dáin was a descendant of [[Grór]] and lord of the [[Dwarves of the Iron Hills]]. Dáin joined his [[Nain son of Gror|father's]] contingent in the [[Battle of Azanulbizar]], at which time he slew [[Azog]]. After Thorin's death in the [[Battle of Five Armies]], Dáin was crowned King of Durin's Folk. He ruled in prosperity as [[King under the Mountain]] for many years until the time of the [[War of the Ring]]. He was slain in the [[Battle of Dale]].
[[Thorin Stonehelm|Thorin III Stonehelm]]{{TA|2866|n}}UnknownEreborThorin himself succeeded to the kingship when his father was killed during the [[War of the Ring]] in {{TA|3019}}. His realm was under the crown and protection of the new [[King of Gondor and Arnor]].{{App|Great}} During his rule, [[Gimli]] led a number of [[Dwarves of Erebor|Dwarves]] south to [[Aglarond]], where a new [[Lord of the Glittering Caves|lordship]] was established.
[[Durin VII]]After {{FoA|171}}
The mention of Durin's name as a prophecy in the [[Appendix A]], and considering that the Appendix derives from the [[Red Book]] (copied {{FoA|171}}), seems to suggest that he was probably born, or emerged, after that date.		UnknownKhazad-dûm{{PM|Aiv}}He was the last of the reincarnations of [[Durin]] hence his title as "Durin the Last". He was a direct descendant of [[Thorin III Stonehelm]].An alternative version of the genealogical tree of [[Appendix A]] suggested Durin VII was the son of Thorin III.{{PM|Aiv}}, p. 279 His birth was apparently prophesied upon the accession of [[Dáin II]] after the [[Battle of Five Armies]].{{PM|Aiv}}, p. 383 He led [[Durin's Folk]] back to [[Khazad-dûm]] at some unknown time after {{FoA|171}}, where they remained "until the world grew old and the Dwarves failed and the days of Durin's race were ended".{{PM|Aiv}}, p. 278
Durin I died before the end of the First Age, so that between his rule and that of Thorin III, the Kings of Durin's line ruled for a period of about 6,500 years. Given that the average length of a reign among the Longbeards seems to have been roughly a century, it can be deduced that there were probably about fifty Kings that have went unmentioned. {{References|notes}} {{durinskings}} [[Category:Dwarven titles]] [[Category:Kings of Durin's Folk| ]] [[de:Durins Volk#Stammbaum]] [[fr:encyclo/personnages/nains/rois du peuple de durin]] [[fi:Durinin heimon kuninkaat]]
